channel.title: Auxy tracks on Spotify
channel.description:
Hey guys,
I was looking at trying to upload my tracks on Spotify because I use that to listen to music rather than Soundcloud nowadays. I did some digging and apparently a producer has to upload the music to Spotify for us. Is that something that you could see yourselves doing as an app or is there an alternative way for us to upload our music to streaming services like Spotify.
Thanks
h.

item.title: Auxy tracks on Spotify
item.dc:creator: anon6476606
item.description:
Weird. Well, I guess your artist name just fits. But for me, instead of having 3-5 days moderation, it takes 2 weeks and then they reject it and make me do capital S for my name. But ya know, it’s different for everyone I guess

Read full topic

item.title: Auxy tracks on Spotify
item.dc:creator: BlaMeese
item.description:
Yeah I’m having some major troubles with my release right now so i’m just getting it deleted. I switched to using Amuse and it takes me about 5 minutes to put everything together and send it in for review. Every time I send an e-mail they reply within a day and if RoutNote hadn’t screwed things up it would’ve been released by now.

Read full topic

item.title: Auxy tracks on Spotify
item.dc:creator: Cheddr
item.description:
I made a playlist I called Auxians a while ago for my own use including people that I knew were on Spotify. I just realized that I could make it “collaborative” like one of the above posters suggested.

Auxians On Spotify Playlist

Feel free to add your own work to this playlist if you like. Give it a listen to get each of us some plays, right?

Read full topic

item.title: Auxy tracks on Spotify
item.dc:creator: ST3R30
item.description:
I’ve used RouteNote for the 4 singles, 1 album , and 1 EP that I have on spotify. For me it takes about 3-5 days to get approved, and 1-2 days to get on spotify itself. so way less than a month. RouteNote really isn’t bad. The website is a bit slow but that’s about it. The specific file types aren’t a problem either.

Read full topic

item.title: Auxy tracks on Spotify
item.dc:creator: anon6476606
item.description:
The iOS and Android apps are very lacking, especially the iOS one. Spotify, however, invests lots of effort and time into their mobile apps, considering that most traffic on Spotify is from mobile (not an actual statistic, but pretty obvious if you think about it). Thus, the app works

It just

works.

Read full topic

item.title: Auxy tracks on Spotify
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
Ahaa. I’ve never noticed that in the browser version. D’oh!

It’s not available on the iOS app version.

Which means I’d have to use the iOS browser version, which is more effort than it should be.

Interesting, but I’ll stick with my Spotify+local files approach. A little bit of effort upfront saves me a lot of hassle every time.

Read full topic

item.title: Auxy tracks on Spotify
item.dc:creator: anon6476606
item.description:
Aw please don’t use RouteNote. It’s terrible. It’s very slow, has horrible support, and takes more than a month to get on there. Also, you have to upload very specific file types.

Blah.

Basically, it’s not worth it. If you can’t do mobile, try FreshTunes.com. Not as good as Amuse, but infinitely better than RouteNote.

Read full topic

item.title: Auxy tracks on Spotify
item.dc:creator: anon6476606
item.description:
akabillposters:

One of the things I like about SC (Pro accounts), is the ability to update/replace the source audio file without losing play counts, etc… Is that possible using something like Amuse?

AH! This is very interesting.

So every track you put on Spotify or other stores has an “ISRC”. You may know about this already, but here’s an overview: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Standard_Recording_Code

Basically, if your track is distributed onto Spotify in a different fashion (e.g. a compilation album), and they have the same artist name, title, song length, and ISRC, they will count the plays as the same. HOWEVER, an ISRC is needed for each edition of a song. Usually this would be like Radio Edit, Extended Mix, or Alternate Version, but if you want to actually change the song, it has the same effect. So unless the second version is the same song length, you can use the same ISRC and keep the stats!

akabillposters:

It means I can also listen to a track I’m still developing on repeat when I’m out and about

Yep! Also, Spotify also allows [Premium] users to download (which just means listening offline, you don’t get WAVs or whatever) songs, and listen when you’re away from internet.

akabillposters:

Are you on there (via a service like Amuse)?

Austin used Amuse, yes

Read full topic

item.title: Auxy tracks on Spotify
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
Are you on there (via a service like Amuse)?

What’s the process and what’s the turnaround from you uploading to it appearing on Spotify?

One of the things I like about SC (Pro accounts), is the ability to update/replace the source audio file without losing play counts, etc… Is that possible using something like Amuse?

 
Re: quality

I use Spotify’s local files features to keep everything I have on SC on my iPhone/iPad as well. (The Music app would work as well, but I prefer to use Spotify for certain local files as it’s my go-to mobile app for music.)

It means I can also listen to a track I’m still developing on repeat when I’m out and about. SC doesn’t support simple repeat, afaik.

Read full topic

item.description:
